Award.AwardTitle: Small Grants for Collaborative Research in the Americas (SGP-CRA)
Award.AbstractNarration:
To be able to build on the best of its Collaborative Research Networks, the IAI has asked investigators of its current CRN2 (GEO-0452325) and Small Grants Program-Human Dimensions (GEO-0642841) to submit proposals to advance the best science, most promising research initiatives, and to support the most innovative cross-disciplinary teams. The current proposal seeks funding for research to be conducted as sub-awards under that call. Outstanding proposals have been selected through review and panel evaluation by the IAI?s Scientific Advisory Committee. Of the current 21 CRN & SGP-HD projects, 13 submitted proposals, of which 9 were selected for possible funding.

The proposed program has a broader impact beyond its research though integration with decision makers from IAI member countries, through facilitating stakeholder participation in the science, and through the consolidation of international science collaboration networks and institutional links. Multidisciplinary participation in each project, particularly between the natural and human sciences not only enriches the research program but also guides IAI science governance towards its mandate of providing the best science for informed decision making on issues of global change on the continent.

The Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research (IAI) was created by an international agreement concluded among representatives of American States, namely the Agreement Establishing the Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research, done at Montevideo on May 13, 1992 ('the IAI Agreement'). The IAI Agreement created an intergovernmental organization for the purposes of coordinating and promoting scientific research related to global change. The Institute has an evolving 'Scientific Agenda' identifying particular areas for research. Full membership in the IAI is limited to States.

The Institute is governed by an annual Conference of the Parties, and by a subsidiary Executive Council (EC). The US Government currently chairs the EC. The IAI possesses the fundamental institutional characteristics of an international organization: it was created by international agreement, is composed of States and is governed by governing bodies composed of representatives of States.

The US Government participates actively in the IAI. The United States played a leading role in the creation of the IAI and has been an active participant in the IAI since its creation. Senior US Government officials have served on the Executive Council and held other responsible positions related to IAI activities. Furthermore, the IAI has been listed by the State Department and by the Office of Personnel Management as an international organization within the meaning of the Federal Employees International Organization Service Act, covered by 5 U.S.C. 3343 and 5 U.S.C. 3581, and as such has been recognized by State and OPM as a legitimate International Treaty Organization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF grants to the IAI, an intergovernmental treaty-based scientific organization of the US and 18 member countries in the Americas, fund unique multinational, multidisciplinary research that advances science, develops the capacity of researchers and contributes to regional policy-making. Through its direct connections to national governments, IAI brings together scientists and decision makers to address global change in the Americas. This grant selected the best proposals from an existing large research network program to fund the most innovative work on global change and its importance for society.  76 researchers in 53 institutions across 13 countries engaged in 9 projects involving nearly 600 students.

Global environmental change is one of the greatest challenges that humanity faces today. Understanding those changes and how they affect countries beyond national borders will help guide future actions related to risk, vulnerability and adaptation.

How to produce on the land and at the same time conserve ecosystems and the benefits they provide? In semi-arid regions rainfall is scarce but can be intense and cause run-off, flooding and high water tables. One team monitored groundwater and rainfall, worked with producers, and explored how communities should take decisions on landuse that take into account both productivity on any one farm and water distribution between farms across the landscape. Dedicating some arable land to plants that use much water can alleviate groundwater problems, but to decide who benefits and who sets land aside requires new levels of community governance at the landscape and watershed level. The analysis of such decision making processes was taken one step further by another team that analyzed the links between agriculture, water and energy. The resulting political complexity was explored at community, regional and cross-boundary international levels. Rather than provide conclusive results, the strength of the project was the "educated" dialogue initiated between different sectors of society. A separate study using tree rings, to detect historical changes in the water cycle of the American Cordillera, confirmed the impact of climate variability on the fate of societies: villages disappearing and fortifications being built in times of conflict over scarce water resources.

The benefits of natural vegetation and biodiversity must be balanced against society's need for production. One team engaged in demonstrating the service value of ecosystems, and provided their knowledge to legislators.  The resulting decision making, though, did not reflect the scientific argument but instead was a result of power balances, influence, public opinions and economics. This learning process may make future decisions more balanced between production and conservation.

The understanding of ecosystem function and how it is affected by climate change was also studied in dry forests using environmental monitoring with automated observation of the stages of plant development, monitoring of energy and water balances at the land-atmosphere boundary. One aim was to make such technology affordable and wide-spread to help informed decision making. The decision to launch Costa Rica's first land and climate observation satellite was one result of this research and development effort.

Agriculture experiences multiple stressors: not only climate variability and trends, but also market shocks and price volatility, diseases and pests. High value crops such as coffee are often produced in vulnerable family operations. One research team found that small coffee producers could reduce risks and increase their ability to adapt to changes by developing marketing chains that provide a premium for ecological or product certification. Community engagement and the pooling of resources were critical for the success of these efforts.
